verses.verse: Then Job <S%H347><s%> answered, <S%H6030><s%>
"Truly <S%H551><s%> I know <S%H3045><s%> that it is so, <S%H582><s%> but how can man be just <S%H6663><s%> with God? <S%H410><s%>
If he is <S%H2654><s%> pleased to contend <S%H7378><s%> with him, <S%H6030><s%> he can't answer him one <S%H259><s%> time in a thousand. <S%H505><s%>
God who is wise <S%H2450><s%> in heart, <S%H3824><s%> and mighty <S%H533><s%> in strength: <S%H3581><s%> who has hardened <S%H7185><s%> himself against him, <S%H7999><s%> and prospered?
He removes <S%H6275><s%> the mountains, <S%H2022><s%> and they don't <S%H3045><s%> know it, <S%H2015><s%> when he overturns them in his anger. <S%H639><s%>
He shakes <S%H7264><s%> the earth <S%H776><s%> out of its place. <S%H4725><s%> Its pillars <S%H5982><s%> tremble. <S%H6426><s%>
He commands <S%H559><s%> the sun, <S%H2775><s%> and it doesn't <S%H2224><s%> rise, and seals up <S%H2856><s%> the stars. <S%H3556><s%>
He alone stretches out <S%H5186><s%> the heavens, <S%H8064><s%> and treads <S%H1869><s%> on the waves <S%H1116><s%> of the sea. <S%H3220><s%>
He makes <S%H6213><s%> the Bear, <S%H5906><s%> Orion, <S%H3685><s%> and the Pleiades, <S%H3598><s%> and the rooms <S%H2315><s%> of the south. <S%H8486><s%>
He does <S%H6213><s%> great things <S%H1419><s%> past <S%H369><s%> finding out; <S%H2714><s%> yes, <S%H6381><s%> marvelous things without number. <S%H4557><s%>
Behold, <S%H5674><s%> he goes by me, <S%H7200><s%> and I don't see him. <S%H2498><s%> He passes on also, <S%H995><s%> but I don't perceive him.
Behold, <S%H2862><s%> he snatches away. Who can hinder <S%H7725><s%> him? <S%H559><s%> Who will ask him, <S%H6213><s%> 'What are you doing?'
"God <S%H433><s%> will not withdraw <S%H7725><s%> his anger. <S%H639><s%> The helpers <S%H5826><s%> of Rahab <S%H7293><s%> stoop under him. <S%H7817><s%>
How much less shall I answer <S%H6030><s%> him, <S%H977><s%> And choose my words to argue with him? <S%H1697><s%>
Though I were righteous, <S%H6663><s%> yet I wouldn't <S%H6030><s%> answer him. <S%H2603><s%> I would make supplication to my judge. <S%H8199><s%>
If I had called, <S%H7121><s%> and he had answered <S%H6030><s%> me, <S%H539><s%> yet I wouldn't believe that he listened <S%H238><s%> to my voice. <S%H6963><s%>
For he breaks <S%H7779><s%> me with a storm, <S%H8183><s%> and multiplies <S%H7235><s%> my wounds <S%H6482><s%> without cause. <S%H2600><s%>
He will not allow <S%H5414><s%> me to catch <S%H7725><s%> my breath, <S%H7307><s%> but fills <S%H7646><s%> me with bitterness. <S%H4472><s%>
If it is a matter of strength, <S%H3581><s%> behold, <S%H533><s%> he is mighty! If of justice, <S%H4941><s%> <S%H3259><s%> 'Who,' says he, 'will summon me?'
Though I am righteous, <S%H6663><s%> my own mouth <S%H6310><s%> shall condemn <S%H7561><s%> me. <S%H8535><s%> Though I am blameless, it shall prove me perverse. <S%H6140><s%>
I am blameless. <S%H8535><s%> I don't <S%H3045><s%> respect myself. <S%H5315><s%> I despise <S%H3988><s%> my life. <S%H5315><s%>
"It is all the <S%H259><s%> same. <S%H559><s%> Therefore I say he destroys <S%H3615><s%> the blameless <S%H8535><s%> and the wicked. <S%H7563><s%>
If the scourge <S%H7752><s%> kills <S%H4191><s%> suddenly, <S%H6597><s%> he will mock <S%H3932><s%> at the trial <S%H4531><s%> of the innocent. <S%H5355><s%>

The earth <S%H776><s%> is given <S%H5414><s%> into the hand <S%H3027><s%> of the wicked. <S%H7563><s%> He covers <S%H3680><s%> the faces <S%H6440><s%> of its judges. <S%H8199><s%> If not he, <S%H645><s%> then who is it?
"Now my days <S%H3117><s%> are swifter <S%H7043><s%> than a runner. <S%H7323><s%> They flee away, <S%H1272><s%> they see <S%H7200><s%> no good, <S%H2896><s%>
They have passed away <S%H2498><s%> as <S%H5973><s%> the swift <S%H16><s%> ships, <S%H591><s%> as the eagle <S%H5404><s%> that swoops <S%H2907><s%> on the prey. <S%H400><s%>
If I say, <S%H559><s%> <S%H7911><s%> 'I will forget my complaint, <S%H7879><s%> I will put off <S%H5800><s%> my sad face, <S%H6440><s%> and cheer up; <S%H1082><s%>'
I am afraid <S%H3025><s%> of all my sorrows, <S%H6094><s%> I know <S%H3045><s%> that you will not hold me innocent. <S%H5352><s%>
I shall be condemned. <S%H7561><s%> Why then do I labor <S%H3021><s%> in vain? <S%H1892><s%>
If I wash <S%H7364><s%> myself with <S%H7950><s%> snow, <S%H4325><s%> and cleanse <S%H2141><s%> my hands <S%H3709><s%> with lye, <S%H1252><s%>
yet <S%H227><s%> you will plunge <S%H2881><s%> me in the ditch. <S%H7845><s%> My own clothes <S%H8008><s%> shall abhor me. <S%H8581><s%>
For he is not a man, <S%H376><s%> as I am, <S%H6030><s%> that I should answer him, <S%H935><s%> that we should come together <S%H3162><s%> in judgment. <S%H4941><s%>
There is <S%H3426><s%> no umpire <S%H3198><s%> between us, <S%H7896><s%> that might lay his hand <S%H3027><s%> on us both. <S%H8147><s%>
Let him take <S%H5493><s%> his rod <S%H7626><s%> away <S%H5493><s%> from me. <S%H367><s%> Let his terror not make me afraid; <S%H367><s%>
then I would speak, <S%H1696><s%> and not fear him, <S%H3372><s%> for I am not so in myself.
